The **World War II Memorial** is a [memorial of national
significance](/wiki/List_of_National_Memorials_of_the_United_States "List of
National Memorials of the United States")[1][2] dedicated to
[Americans](/wiki/United_States "United States") who served in the [armed
forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces") and as
civilians during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). Consisting
of 56 pillars and a pair of small [triumphal arches](/wiki/Triumphal_arch
"Triumphal arch") surrounding a square and fountain, it sits on the [National
Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall") in [Washington,
D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), on the former site of the
[Rainbow Pool](/wiki/Rainbow_Pool "Rainbow Pool") at the eastern end of the
[Reflecting Pool](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial_Reflecting_Pool "Lincoln Memorial
Reflecting Pool"), between the [Lincoln Memorial](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial
"Lincoln Memorial") and the [Washington Monument](/wiki/Washington_Monument
"Washington Monument").

Opened on April 29, 2004, it was dedicated by
[President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") on May 29,
2004.[3] The memorial is administered by the [National Park
Service](/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service") under its
[National Mall and Memorial Parks](/wiki/National_Mall_and_Memorial_Parks
"National Mall and Memorial Parks") group.[4] As of 2009, more than 4.4
million people visit the memorial each year.[_[not verified in
body](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

##
Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Design")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Aerial_view_of_National_World_War_II_Memorial.jpg/220px-
Aerial_view_of_National_World_War_II_Memorial.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_National_World_War_II_Memorial.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_National_World_War_II_Memorial.jpg "Enlarge")

Aerial view of the World War II Memorial

The memorial consists of 56 [granite](/wiki/Granite "Granite")
[pillars](/wiki/Column "Column"), each 17 feet (5.2 m) tall, arranged in a
[semicircle](/wiki/Semicircle "Semicircle") around a [plaza](/wiki/Plaza
"Plaza") with two 43-foot (13 m) [triumphal arches](/wiki/Triumphal_arch
"Triumphal arch") on opposite sides. Two-thirds of the 7.4-acre (30,000 m2)
site is landscaping and water. Each pillar is inscribed with the name of one
of the 48 [U.S. states](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") of 1945, as well as the
[District of Columbia](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), the [Alaska
Territory](/wiki/Alaska_Territory "Alaska Territory") and [Territory of
Hawaii](/wiki/Territory_of_Hawaii "Territory of Hawaii"), the [Commonwealth of
the Philippines](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines "Commonwealth of the
Philippines"), [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"),
[Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"), [American Samoa](/wiki/American_Samoa "American
Samoa"), and the [U.S. Virgin Islands](/wiki/U.S._Virgin_Islands "U.S. Virgin
Islands"). The northern arch is inscribed with
"[Atlantic](/wiki/European_Theatre_of_World_War_II "European Theatre of World
War II")"; the southern one, "[Pacific](/wiki/Asiatic-Pacific_Theater
"Asiatic-Pacific Theater")." The plaza is 337 ft 10 in (102.97 m) long and 240
feet 2 inches (73.20 m) wide, is sunk 6 feet (1.8 m) below
[grade](/wiki/Grade_\(slope\) "Grade \(slope\)"), and contains a pool that is
246 feet 9 inches by 147 feet 8 inches (75.2 × 45.0 m).[5]

The memorial includes two[6] inconspicuously located "[Kilroy was
here](/wiki/Kilroy_was_here "Kilroy was here")" engravings. Their inclusion in
the memorial acknowledges the significance of the symbol to American soldiers
during World War II and how it represented their presence and protection
wherever it was inscribed.[7]

On approaching the semicircle from the east, a visitor walks along one of two
walls (right side wall and left side wall) picturing scenes of the war
experience in bas relief. As one approaches on the left (toward the Pacific
arch), the scenes begin with soon-to-be servicemen getting physical exams,
taking the oath, and being issued military gear. The reliefs progress through
several iconic scenes, including combat and burying the dead, ending in a
homecoming scene. On the right-side wall (toward the Atlantic arch) there is a
similar progression, but with scenes generally more typical of the European
theatre. Some scenes take place in England, depicting the preparations for air
and sea assaults. The last scene is of [a handshake between the American and
Russian armies](/wiki/Elbe_Day "Elbe Day") when the western and eastern fronts
met in Germany.

### Freedom
Wall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Freedom Wall")]

The Freedom Wall is on the west side of the memorial, with a view of the
[Reflecting Pool](/wiki/Reflecting_Pool "Reflecting Pool") and Lincoln
Memorial behind it. The wall has 4,048 gold stars, each representing 100
Americans who died in the war. In front of the wall lies the message "Here we
mark the price of freedom".[8]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Natww2.jpg/170px-
Natww2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Natww2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Natww2.jpg "Enlarge")

View of The World War II Memorial (bottom) and the Lincoln Memorial (top) from
the Washington Monument

In 1987, World War II veteran Roger Durbin approached Representative [Marcy
Kaptur](/wiki/Marcy_Kaptur "Marcy Kaptur"), a
[Democrat](/wiki/United_States_Democratic_Party "United States Democratic
Party") from [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio"), to ask if a World War II memorial
could be constructed. Kaptur introduced the World War II Memorial Act to the
[House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives
"United States House of Representatives") as HR 3742 on December 10. The
resolution authorized the [American Battle Monuments
Commission](/wiki/American_Battle_Monuments_Commission "American Battle
Monuments Commission") (ABMC) to establish a World War II memorial in
"Washington, D.C., or its environs", but the bill was not voted on before the
end of the session, so it was not passed. Two more times, in 1989 and 1991,
Rep. Kaptur introduced similar legislation, but these bills suffered the same
fate as the first, and did not become law.

Kaptur reintroduced legislation in the House a fourth time as HR 682 on
January 27, 1993, one day after Senator [Strom Thurmond](/wiki/Strom_Thurmond
"Strom Thurmond") (a [Republican](/wiki/United_States_Republican_Party "United
States Republican Party") from [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South
Carolina")) introduced companion Senate legislation. On March 17, 1993, the
Senate approved the act, and the House approved an amended version of the bill
on May 4. On May 12, the Senate also approved the amended bill, and the World
War II Memorial Act was signed into law by President [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") on May 25 of that year, becoming
Public Law 103-32.

###
Fundraising[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Fundraising")]

On September 30, 1994, President [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill
Clinton") appointed a 12-member Memorial Advisory Board (MAB) to advise the
ABMC in picking the site, designing the memorial, and raising money to build
it. A [direct mail](/wiki/Direct_mail "Direct mail") fundraising effort
brought in millions of dollars from individual Americans. Additional large
donations were made by veterans' groups, including the [American
Legion](/wiki/American_Legion "American Legion"), the [Veterans of Foreign
Wars](/wiki/Veterans_of_Foreign_Wars "Veterans of Foreign Wars"), Veterans of
the Battle of the Bulge and others. The majority of the corporate fundraising
effort was led by two co-chairs: Senator [Bob Dole](/wiki/Bob_Dole "Bob
Dole"), a decorated World War II veteran and 1996 Republican nominee for
president; and [Frederick W. Smith](/wiki/Frederick_W._Smith "Frederick W.
Smith"), the [president](/wiki/President "President") and [chief executive
officer](/wiki/Chief_executive_officer "Chief executive officer") of [FedEx
Corporation](/wiki/FedEx_Corporation "FedEx Corporation") and a former [U.S.
Marine Corps](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps")
officer. The [U.S. federal
government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government
of the United States") provided about $16 million. A total of $197 million was
raised.

### Picking the
site[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Picking the site")]

On January 20, 1995, Colonel Kevin C. Kelley, project manager for the ABMC,
organized the first meeting of the ABMC and the MAB, at which the project was
discussed and initial plans made. The meeting was chaired by Commissioner F.
Haydn Williams, chairman of ABMC's World War II Memorial Site and Design
Committee, who would go on to guide the project through the site selection and
approval process and the selection and approval of the Memorial's design.
Representatives from the [United States Commission of Fine
Arts](/wiki/United_States_Commission_of_Fine_Arts "United States Commission of
Fine Arts"), the [National Capital Planning
Commission](/wiki/National_Capital_Planning_Commission "National Capital
Planning Commission"), the [National Capital Memorial
Commission](/wiki/National_Capital_Memorial_Commission "National Capital
Memorial Commission"), the [U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "United States Army
Corps of Engineers"), and the National Park Service attended the meeting.
Selection of an appropriate site was taken on as the first action.

Over the next months, several sites were considered. Three quickly gained
favor:[9][10]

  * [U.S. Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") [Reflection Pool](/wiki/Capitol_Reflection_Pool "Capitol Reflection Pool") area – between 3rd Street and the [Ulysses S. Grant Memorial](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant_Memorial "Ulysses S. Grant Memorial")
  * [Constitution Gardens](/wiki/Constitution_Gardens "Constitution Gardens") – east end, between [Constitution Avenue](/wiki/Constitution_Avenue "Constitution Avenue") and the [Rainbow Pool](/wiki/Rainbow_Pool "Rainbow Pool")
  * [Freedom Plaza](/wiki/Freedom_Plaza "Freedom Plaza") – on [Pennsylvania Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue_\(Washington,_D.C.\) "Pennsylvania Avenue \(Washington, D.C.\)") between [14th](/wiki/14th_Street_Northwest_and_Southwest_\(Washington,_D.C.\) "14th Street Northwest and Southwest \(Washington, D.C.\)") and 15th Streets

Other sites considered but quickly rejected were:

  * [Tidal Basin](/wiki/Tidal_Basin "Tidal Basin") – northeast side, east of the Tidal Basin parking lot and west of the 14th Street Bridge access road
  * [West Potomac Park](/wiki/West_Potomac_Park "West Potomac Park") – between [Ohio Drive](/wiki/Ohio_Drive "Ohio Drive") and the north shore of the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River"), northwest of the [Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial](/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt_Memorial "Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial")
  * Grounds of the Washington Monument – at Constitution Avenue between 14th and 15th Streets, west of the [National Museum of American History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_American_History "National Museum of American History")
  * [Henderson Hall](/wiki/Henderson_Hall_\(Arlington,_Virginia\) "Henderson Hall \(Arlington, Virginia\)"), adjacent to [Arlington National Cemetery](/wiki/Arlington_National_Cemetery "Arlington National Cemetery") – dropped from consideration because of its unavailability

The selection of the Rainbow Pool site was announced on October 5, 1995. The
design would incorporate the Rainbow Pool fountain, located across 17th Street
from the Washington Monument and near the Constitution Gardens site.[11]

The location is itself a significant symbol. The memorial will be given a more
prominent spot than any monument on the National Mall since the Lincoln
Memorial opened in 1922. The location, between the Washington Monument and the
Lincoln Memorial, represents the first addition in more than 70 years to the
grand corridor of open space that stretches from the Capitol 2.1 miles west to
the Potomac River.[12]

### Designing the
memorial[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Designing the memorial")]

A nationwide design competition drew 400 submissions from architects from
around the country. [Friedrich St. Florian](/wiki/Friedrich_St._Florian
"Friedrich St. Florian")'s initial design was selected in 1997. Over the next
four years, St. Florian's design was altered during the review and approval
process required of proposed memorials in Washington, D.C. Ambassador Haydn
Williams guided the design development for ABMC.

St. Florian's design consists of an architectural sculpture that evokes a
classical monument. The two memorial arches, Pacific and Atlantic baldacchinos
each have laurel wreaths suspended in the air with 4 eagles carrying it. The
chandelier sculpture symbolizes the victory of the War with the Nation's bird
carrying a Grecian symbol of victory but with an American adaptation of oak
laurel wreaths to symbolize strength.

Each of the 56 pillars all consists of oak laurel wreaths and wheat laurel
wreath. The oak symbolizes military and industrial strength and the wheat
symbolizes agricultural and breadbasket during the U.S. part in the war.

##
Construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Construction")]

Ground was broken in September 2001. The construction was managed by the
[General Services Administration](/wiki/General_Services_Administration
"General Services Administration").

The triumphal arches were crafted by [Rock of Ages
Corporation](/wiki/Rock_of_Ages_Corporation "Rock of Ages Corporation").
Sculptor [Raymond Kaskey](/wiki/Raymond_Kaskey "Raymond Kaskey") created the
bronze eagles and wreaths that were installed under the arches, as well as 24
bronze [bas-relief](/wiki/Bas-relief "Bas-relief") panels that depict wartime
scenes of combat and the home front.[13] The bronzes were cast over the course
of two and a half years at Laran Bronze in [Chester,
Pennsylvania](/wiki/Chester,_Pennsylvania "Chester, Pennsylvania").[14] The
stainless-steel armature that holds up the eagles and wreaths was designed at
Laran, in part by sculptor [James Peniston](/wiki/James_Peniston "James
Peniston"),[15] and fabricated by Apex Piping of [Newport,
Delaware](/wiki/Newport,_Delaware "Newport, Delaware").[16]

[The John Stevens Shop](/wiki/The_John_Stevens_Shop "The John Stevens Shop")
designed the lettering for the memorial and most of the inscriptions were
hand-carved in situ.

The memorial opened to the public on April 29, 2004, and was dedicated in a
May 29 ceremony attended by thousands of people. The memorial became a
[national park](/wiki/National_park "National park") on November 1, when
authority over it was transferred to the National Park Service.

In 2012, the memorial's fountain was renovated.[17]

##
Controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Controversy")]

### Criticism of the
location[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Criticism of the location")]

Critics such as the National Coalition to Save Our Mall opposed the location
of the memorial. A major criticism of the location was that it would interrupt
what had been an unbroken view between the Washington Monument and the Lincoln
Memorial. The memorial was also criticized for taking up open space that had
been historically used for major
[demonstrations](/wiki/Demonstration_\(people\) "Demonstration \(people\)")
and [protests](/wiki/Protest "Protest").[18][19][20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Washington_Monument_View.jpg/220px-
Washington_Monument_View.jpg)](/wiki/File:Washington_Monument_View.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Washington_Monument_View.jpg "Enlarge")

Washington Monument View

Critics were particularly bothered by the expedited approval process, which is
considerably lengthy most of the time.[21] The United States Congress, worried
that World War II veterans were dying before an appropriate memorial could be
built, passed legislation exempting the World War II Memorial from further
site and design review. Congress also dismissed pending legal challenges to
the memorial.[22]

### Criticism of the design and
style[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Criticism of the design and style")]

There were also aesthetic objections to the design. A critic from the _[Boston
Herald](/wiki/Boston_Herald "Boston Herald")_ described the monument as
"vainglorious, demanding of attention and full of trite imagery."[23] _[The
Philadelphia Inquirer](/wiki/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer "The Philadelphia
Inquirer")_ argued that "this pompous style was also favored by
[Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") and
[Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini")"[24] (see [Nazi
architecture](/wiki/Nazi_architecture "Nazi architecture")). The _[Washington
Post](/wiki/Washington_Post "Washington Post")_ described it as "overbearing",
"bombastic", and a "hodgepodge of cliche and Soviet-style pomposity" with "the
emotional impact of a slab of granite".[25]

Some supporters said that the design evoked federal architecture during the
[New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") period, influenced by an austere
interpretation of [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco")/[Beaux
Arts](/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture "Beaux-Arts architecture")
styles.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] This view, and the monument, were dismissed by one prominent
architecture critic as "knee-jerk [historicism](/wiki/Historicism_\(art\)
"Historicism \(art\)")"[26]

### FDR's D-Day
prayer[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_World_War_II_Memorial&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: FDR's D-Day prayer")]

On May 23, 2013, Senator [Rob Portman](/wiki/Rob_Portman "Rob Portman")
introduced the [World War II Memorial Prayer Act of 2013 (S. 1044; 113th
Congress)](/wiki/World_War_II_Memorial_Prayer_Act_of_2013_\(S._1044;_113th_Congress\)
"World War II Memorial Prayer Act of 2013 \(S. 1044; 113th Congress\)"), a
bill that would direct the [United States Secretary of the
Interior](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Interior "United States
Secretary of the Interior") to install at the World War II memorial in the
[District of Columbia](/wiki/District_of_Columbia "District of Columbia") a
suitable plaque or an inscription with the words that President [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") prayed with
the United States on June 6, 1944, the morning of [D-Day](/wiki/D-Day
"D-Day").[27] The bill was opposed by the [American Civil Liberties
Union](/wiki/American_Civil_Liberties_Union "American Civil Liberties Union"),
the [American Jewish Committee](/wiki/American_Jewish_Committee "American
Jewish Committee"), [Americans United for Separation of Church and
State](/wiki/Americans_United_for_Separation_of_Church_and_State "Americans
United for Separation of Church and State"), the [Hindu American
Foundation](/wiki/Hindu_American_Foundation "Hindu American Foundation"), and
the [Interfaith Alliance](/wiki/Interfaith_Alliance "Interfaith
Alliance").[28] Together the organizations argued that the bill "endorses the
false notion that all veterans will be honored by a war memorial that includes
a prayer proponents characterize as reflecting our country's 'Judeo-Christian
heritage and values.'"[28] The organizations argued that "the memorial, as it
currently stands, appropriately honors those who served and encompasses the
entirety of the war" and was carefully created, so no additional elements,
such as FDR's prayer, need to be added.[28] But, they said, "the effect of
this bill, however, is to co-opt religion for political purposes, which harms
the beliefs of everyone."[28] The bill passed in the [United States
Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") on June 5,
2014.[29]
